metadata.titleEn: Antarctic sea ice extent reconstruction over the past 200 years
metadata.description: (1) Data content: data set of Antarctic sea ice extent (Northernmost Latitude of Sea Ice Edge (NLSIE) [°N]) in the past 200 years; (2) Data source and processing method: the data is generated based on the statistical model using six annual resolution proxies (ice core MSA, accumulation rate, etc.); (3) Data quality description: annual resolution; Areas: Indian and western Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean  (50 ° – 150 ° E, indwpac), Ross Sea (160 ° E – 140 ° W, RS), Amundsen Sea (90 ° – 140 ° W, as), Bellingshausen Sea (50 ° – 90 ° W, BS), Weddell Sea (50 ° W – 20 ° E, WS); (4) It can be used to study the interdecadal variability of Antarctic sea ice.

background: The shortness of the satellite record limits our ability to quantify the possible contribution of anthropogenic forcing and internal variability to the observed Antarctic sea ice variability. Satellite observations have shown that sea ice in the Arctic has been declining rapidly over the last 40 years, which is consistent with the expectation of amplified Arctic warming due to ice-albedo feedback. In contrast, the total sea ice extent (SIE) in the Antarctic showed a slight but significantly increasing trend from 1979 to 2015, although this trend did not continue in recent years (2016–2018), during which anomalously low ice cover was observed. Coupled climate models have had limited success in correctly simulating fundamental aspects of the observed annual cycle and the long-term trends. Multiple factors contribute to the observed trends of Antarctic SIE. The cooling of surface waters in the Southern Ocean due to the observed strengthening of the westerly winds and upward trend in the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) might be another factor resulting in the positive trend in Antarctic SIE. The satellite data record in the Antarctic is quite short; it begins in the late 1970s, and the discrepancies between observations and model simulations limit our understanding of Antarctic sea ice variability and its links to regional climate over longer periods, especially at the multi-decadal scale. Using paleoclimate archives is the best approach for reconstructing the past sea ice state. Several studies have reconstructed past changes in Antarctic sea ice using various proxy data extracted from ice cores. Reconstructions of sea ice around Antarctica from regional to continental scales are essential to estimate the contribution of internal and external forcings in Antarctic sea ice variability and evaluate climate model simulations.
research objective: In this study, ice core and fast ice records with annual resolution from six sites are used to reconstruct the annual-resolved northernmost latitude of sea ice edge (NLSIE) for different sectors of the Southern Ocean, including the Weddell Sea (WS), Bellingshausen Sea (BS), Amundsen Sea (AS), Ross Sea (RS), and the Indian and western Pacific Ocean (IndWPac). To improve projections for the coming decades, an understanding of the interactions of teleconnections and local feedback mechanisms at longer time scales is needed. In this study, we use ice-core-based reconstructions to examine the regional and overall changes in Antarctic SIE during the past 100–200 years. We also discuss the possible mechanisms responsible for the identified variations in the context of climate variability at the multi-decadal scale.
challenges: The shortness of the satellite record limits our ability to quantify the possible contribution of anthropogenic forcing and internal variability to the observed Antarctic sea ice variability. Coupled climate models have had limited success in correctly simulating fundamental aspects of the observed annual cycle and the long-term trends. The discrepancy between climate models and observations likely stems from climate forcing, rather than sea ice physics. Although these estimates of sea ice changes are generally in agreement, the considerable uncertainties arise from the individual proxies and different indicators employed, and the aforementioned reconstructions and their unified quantization require further validation.
methods: In this study, we used ice core and fast-ice records with annual resolution from six sites to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge (NLSIE) for the following sectors of the Southern Ocean. The NLSIE in WS was reconstructed using the South Orkney Fast-Ice (SOFI) series as a proxy. The NLSIE in BS was reconstructed using the annual net accumulation record from the Bruce Plateau ice core extracted from the Antarctic Peninsula, covering the period of 1900–2009. The NLSIE in AS was reconstructed using SOFI series, given its significant negative correlation with the averaged NLSIE in the 90°–140°W longitudinal band. The NLSIE in RS was reconstructed using the MSA concentration derived from the Ferrigno and Erebus Saddle ice cores. The NLSIE in IndWPac was reconstructed using MSA records obtained from the LGB69 and Law Dome ice cores. The leave-one-out cross-validation method was used to verify the reconstruction results, and the transfer function in each sector was demonstrated to be valid.
dataset: In this study, we used ice core and fast-ice records with annual resolution from six sites to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge (NLSIE) for the following sectors of the Southern Ocean. The SOFI record is an annual record of fast-ice around the South Orkney Islands from 1903 to 2008. The NLSIE in BS was reconstructed using the annual net accumulation record from the Bruce Plateau ice core extracted from the Antarctic Peninsula, covering the period of 1900–2009. The MSA concentration in the Ferrigno ice core was shown to be a robust proxy for winter SIE in RS for the period of 1703–2010. The LGB69 ice core covers 294 years, from 1708 to 2001, and the Law Dome ice core covers 155 years, from 1841 to 1995.
findings: The linear trends of the NLSIE are analyzed for each sector for the past 100–200 years and found to be -0.08°/decade, -0.17°/decade, +0.07°/decade, +0.02°/decade, and -0.03°/decade (95% confidence level) for the WS, BS, AS, RS, and IndWPac, respectively. For the entire Antarctic, our composite NLSIE shows a decreasing trend (-0.03°/decade, 99% confidence level) during the 20th century, with a rapid decline in the mid-1950s. A comparison with major climate indices shows that the long-term linear trends in all five sectors are largely dominated by the changes in the Southern Annular Mode (SAM). The multi-decadal variability in WS, BS, and AS is dominated by the Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation, whereas that in the IndWPac and RS is dominated by the SAM.

Definition.Question: What does 'proxy data' mean in the context of reconstructing Antarctic sea ice extent?
Definition.Answer: In the context of reconstructing Antarctic sea ice extent, 'proxy data' refers to indirect evidence used to infer past climate conditions, such as sea ice extent. This includes data extracted from ice cores, like MSA concentrations and net accumulation records, which serve as proxies for historical sea ice data, allowing researchers to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge over specific time periods.

Definition.Question: What does 'leave-one-out cross-validation' mean in the context of verifying reconstruction results?
Definition.Answer: In the context of verifying reconstruction results, 'leave-one-out cross-validation' is a validation technique where one data point is removed from the dataset, the model is trained on the remaining data, and then tested on the removed data point. This process is repeated for each data point in the dataset to ensure the reliability and validity of the reconstruction model used to estimate the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge.

Comparison.Question: How do ice core records compare to fast-ice records in terms of their effectiveness as proxies for reconstructing the sea ice extent in different sectors of the Southern Ocean?
Comparison.Answer: Ice core records and fast-ice records are both used to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge (NLSIE) for different sectors of the Southern Ocean. Ice cores, such as those from the Bruce Plateau and Ferrigno, provide information on MSA concentrations and net accumulation, which are proxies for sea ice extent. Fast-ice records, like the South Orkney Fast-Ice (SOFI) series, are also used as proxies due to their correlation with sea ice extent. Each method has its effectiveness depending on the sector, with ice cores potentially offering longer historical data and fast-ice records providing more direct local observations.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection and interpretation can be identified from the reliance on proxy records, such as ice cores, for reconstructing sea ice extent over the past centuries?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include the shortness of the satellite record, which limits our ability to fully quantify anthropogenic and natural variability. There are also considerable uncertainties due to the use of different proxies and indicators, and discrepancies between model simulations and observations. These challenges highlight the need for further validation and refinement of reconstruction methodologies to ensure accurate quantification of historical sea ice trends.

Interpretation.Question: How might cross-validation techniques, like leave-one-out cross-validation, contribute to the robustness and reliability of sea ice extent reconstructions in polar climate studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Cross-validation techniques such as leave-one-out cross-validation contribute to robustness by verifying the reconstruction results and ensuring the validity of the transfer function used in each sector. This statistical method helps in assessing the accuracy of the proxy data reconstructions and enhances the reliability of the inferred historical sea ice extents, thereby strengthening conclusions drawn about past climate variability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately reconstructing the past sea ice extent using proxy data from ice cores?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately reconstructing past sea ice extent using proxy data arise from the shortness of the satellite record and the limited success of coupled climate models in simulating observed trends. Additionally, there are considerable uncertainties from individual proxies and indicators used, which require further validation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do coupled climate models face difficulties in simulating the annual cycle and long-term trends of Antarctic sea ice extent?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Coupled climate models face difficulties due to the discrepancies between climate model simulations and observations, which likely stem from issues related to climate forcing rather than sea ice physics. The short satellite record also limits our understanding of long-term variability and trends.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy and reliability when reconstructing sea ice extent using diverse proxy indicators from ice cores?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using diverse proxy indicators from ice cores can lead to considerable uncertainties due to the variability in individual proxies and indicators, which can affect the accuracy and reliability of sea ice extent reconstructions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of ice core and fast-ice records with annual resolution impact our understanding of the long-term trends in Antarctic sea ice variability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of ice core and fast-ice records with annual resolution provides insights into the long-term trends in Antarctic sea ice variability by offering a historical perspective that extends beyond the short satellite record, allowing for the evaluation of climate model simulations and understanding of regional changes over the past 100–200 years.

Causal Consequence.Question: What implications do the challenges of short satellite records and discrepancies between model simulations and observations have on future data collection methods for Antarctic sea ice research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The short satellite records and discrepancies between model simulations and observations highlight the need for improved data collection methods, such as utilizing paleoclimate archives and alternative proxies, to enhance the understanding of Antarctic sea ice variability and address the limitations in simulating long-term trends and climatic impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use ice core and fast-ice records to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of sea ice edge in the Southern Ocean?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using ice core and fast-ice records allows researchers to reconstruct past changes in sea ice around Antarctica, which is essential for estimating the contribution of internal and external forcings in Antarctic sea ice variability and evaluating climate model simulations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to reconstruct the northernmost latitude of the sea ice edge (NLSIE) using proxy data from ice cores?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The reconstruction of NLSIE involves using ice core and fast-ice records with annual resolution from six sites. The NLSIE in the Weddell Sea (WS) is reconstructed using the South Orkney Fast-Ice (SOFI) series as a proxy. In the Bellingshausen Sea (BS), the annual net accumulation record from the Bruce Plateau ice core is used. For the Amundsen Sea (AS), the SOFI series is utilized due to its significant negative correlation with the averaged NLSIE in the 90°–140°W longitudinal band. The Ross Sea (RS) uses MSA concentration derived from the Ferrigno and Erebus Saddle ice cores, while the Indian and western Pacific Ocean (IndWPac) relies on MSA records from the LGB69 and Law Dome ice cores. The leave-one-out cross-validation method is applied to verify the reconstruction results, ensuring the validity of the transfer function in each sector.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the leave-one-out cross-validation method be applied to verify reconstruction results of sea ice edge proxies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The leave-one-out cross-validation method is applied by systematically leaving out one data point from the dataset and using the remaining data to reconstruct the NLSIE. This process is repeated for each data point, allowing for the assessment of the model's predictive power and accuracy. The results from the cross-validation are used to validate the transfer function applied in each sector, ensuring that the reconstruction model is robust and reliable.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges faced in using ice core data as proxies for Antarctic sea ice extent, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in using ice core data as proxies include the shortness of the satellite record, which limits the ability to quantify contributions of anthropogenic forcing and internal variability. There is also a discrepancy between climate models and observations, likely due to climate forcing rather than sea ice physics. Considerable uncertainties arise from individual proxies and different indicators used. These challenges can be addressed by further validating reconstructions and unifying quantization methods. Using paleoclimate archives is a crucial approach for reconstructing past sea ice states, allowing for more accurate estimations of internal and external forcings in Antarctic sea ice variability.

Request/Directive.Answer: Methodological challenges in using ice core data to reconstruct past Antarctic sea ice variability include the shortness of the satellite record, which limits direct comparisons and validation. Additionally, there are uncertainties arising from the individual proxies and indicators used, which require further validation to ensure accuracy.
